description: Heart failure refers to the heart's inability to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. It may result from the heart not filling with enough blood, or the heart not pumping with enough force—sometimes both conditions occur simultaneously. Heart failure does not mean the heart has stopped working, but that it requires medical attention due to its serious dysfunction.
symptoms: Fatigue: slow reactions, poor concentration, reduced physical performance, loss of appetite or nausea
Edema: swelling in the legs and abdomen, weight gain, decreased urine output
Shortness of breath: difficulty breathing when lying flat, relieved by sitting up
Cough and sputum: sputum may be blood-tinged
Irregular heartbeat: rapid or irregular heartbeat
diagnosis: Echocardiogram: checks structure, function, and valve issues
Chest X-ray: assesses heart size, pulmonary edema, pleural effusion
Electrocardiogram (ECG): detects arrhythmias and myocardial ischemia
NT-proBNP: heart failure marker, higher levels indicate more severe condition
Blood tests: liver and kidney function, electrolytes, thyroid function, blood sugar, cholesterol
Coronary angiography, exercise ECG, cardiac catheterization

general: Pay attention to symptoms like shortness of breath, abnormal sputum, irregular heartbeat, and chest pain—seek medical attention early
Weigh yourself daily at the same time; rapid weight gain or swelling warrants a follow-up
Avoid constipation and emotional fluctuations, maintain regular routines, and stay in a good mood
diet: Control salt intake: recommended daily intake is 3–5 grams
Control fluid intake, such as distributing 1200 mL throughout the day
Prevent thirst: avoid high-sodium foods and use oral moisturizing methods
exercise: Engage in activities based on doctor's advice; mild activity is allowed if condition is stable
Avoid overexertion that increases cardiac burden
monitoring: Regularly record weight and symptom changes
Attend follow-ups and take medication as prescribed
lifestyle: Do not adjust medications on your own
Eat high-fiber foods to avoid constipation

domestic: The prevalence of heart failure in Taiwan is about 1 ~ 1.77%
With an aging population, it is projected to reach 3 ~ 4.45% by 2050
Hospitalization and mortality rates are relatively high, so prevention and treatment are important
ethnic: Heart failure incidence and mortality rates are higher in Black populations than in Whites
Blacks with advanced heart failure have lower treatment rates
Different ethnic groups may respond differently to treatment, and medication efficacy may vary
